Selected Answer: B
Variances between organizational risk appetites would present the GREATEST challenge for a risk practitioner during a merger of two organizations.

During a merger of two organizations, there can be significant differences in the risk management practices and risk appetites of each organization. Risk appetite refers to the amount and type of risk that an organization is willing to accept in pursuit of its objectives. When merging two organizations, it is important to reconcile these differences and develop a shared understanding of the risk appetite for the combined entity.

Different taxonomies to categorize risk scenarios can also present a challenge, but can typically be reconciled through a mapping exercise to align the two taxonomies. In contrast, variances in organizational risk appetites may require a more fundamental shift in the way risks are identified, assessed, and managed, as well as potentially different risk tolerances.
